statement:
In the following we will assume that the term “smooth” implies just
$C^1$ (once continuously differentiable). By smooth homotopy we will
that the homotopy mapping is itself continuously differentiable

Suppose that $M$ is a connected, smooth manifold without boundary of
dimension $m$ and suppose $f,g \colon M \to S^m$ are smooth mappings to
the $m$-sphere. Then $f$ and $g$ are smoothly homotopic if and only if
$f$ and $g$ have the same Brouwer degree.

When $M$ is not orientable, then we can always “flip” the orientation by
following a closed loop on the manifold and one can then prove the
following result.

Suppose that $M$ is not orientable, connected smooth manifold without
boundary of dimension $m$, and suppose $f,g \colon M \to S^m$ are smooth
mappings to the $m$-sphere. Then $f$ and $g$ are smoothly homotopic if
and only if $f$ and $g$ have the same degree mod 2.
